title-group.article-title: The dynamics of terror during the Peruvian civil war

contrib.aff: Department of Economics, University of Otago

bio.p: DAVID FIELDING, b. 1965, DPhil in economics (University of Oxford, 1993) is Professor of Economics at the University of Otago. His current main interests are in development macroeconomics and conflict dynamics.

ANJA SHORTLAND, b. 1973, PhD in international relations (LSE, 2002) is senior lecturer in Economics at Brunel University. Her research is on the interaction between political conditions, institutions and economic outcomes. She publishes on conflict dynamics, piracy, the peace dividend and the politics of financial development.

abstract.p: The international community has a declared intention to protect civilians from deliberate violence in civil conflicts. The optimal type of foreign intervention and its optimal timing are likely to depend on the combat strategies of the belligerents. Weak belligerents unable to provide economic incentives and security guarantees to civilians often follow a strategy of intimidation and terror. In this case, foreign financial support for one side could affect the strategies of both sides in several different ways, and the interaction between the two sides’ strategies could magnify the resulting impact on civilian casualties. Using a new monthly time-series dataset, we explore the factors associated with variations in the intensity of civilian abuse by participants in the guerrilla war in Peru during the 1980s and 1990s. We show that an increase in civilian abuse by one side was strongly associated with subsequent increases in abuse by the other. In this type of war, foreign intervention could substantially reduce the impact on civilians of a sudden rise in conflict intensity, by moderating the resulting ‘cycle of violence’. In practice, foreign interventions had a mixed record in Peru: financial support for the Peruvian military raised the level of violence against civilians, but counter-narcotics aid and development aid reduced it. These effects are consistent with a model in which different types of intervention have different effects on belligerents’ resource capacity and on the opportunity cost of fighting.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Violence against innocent civilians in civil war is of concern to the international community, but there is uncertainty about when and how to intervene in such conflicts. Despite ample evidence about variation in the level of violence across different civil wars, little is known about what causes the substantial variation within conflicts over time. For example, in the Uppsala Conflict Data Program Dyadic Dataset (Harbom, Melander & Wallensteen, 2008), the mean number of civilian deaths per dyad per year is 151, but the standard deviation conditional on dyad fixed effects is 312. Some of this variation is accounted for by annually varying dyad characteristics, but much of it remains unexplained. One possible reason for the unexplained variation is that there are large high-frequency shocks to the level of violence which persist for some time afterwards. Persistence could take the form of a ‘cycle of violence’, when more terror by one side this month encourages more terror by the other side next month (Fielding & Shortland, 2010).

The degree of persistence matters because it might help to forecast the level of violence in the near future. It might not be possible to forecast sudden shocks, but if a large shock has occurred, and its effects can be expected to persist, then there is a case for an immediate international policy response. What should this response be? There is some evidence on the effect of peacekeeping operations (Hultman, 2010), but there is little direct evidence on the effect of economic interventions such as foreign aid targeted at one of the belligerents or at the civilians they are terrorizing. Some types of aid might reduce violence against civilians while other types exacerbate it.

This article provides evidence on the dynamics of violence against civilians and on the effects of foreign intervention, using data published by the Peruvian Truth and Reconciliation Commission (www.cverdad.org.pe/ingles/ifinal/index.php). The TRC reports that almost 70,000 Peruvians died between 1980 and 2000 in the violent conflict between the Peruvian security forces and two guerrilla organizations, the Sendero Luminoso (SL) and the Movimiento Revolucionario Tupac Amaru (MRTA). Most casualties were unarmed civilians; some were caught in cross-fire, but many were specifically targeted by both government and rebel forces (Peru Support Group, 2004). Analysis of the data reveals a strong cycle of violence: typically, when one side increased its effort in terrorizing civilians, the other side responded in kind. While there was no direct foreign military intervention in the conflict, the United States and other Western countries did provide aid of different kinds to the Peruvian government. We are able to show that the effect of such intervention on violence against civilians varied according to the type of aid involved.

The next section outlines the history of the Peruvian conflict. This is followed by a theoretical section that motivates our statistical model. We then discuss the TRC data, and the results of fitting our model to these data.

sec.title: Historical background
sec.p: Sendero Luminoso originated as a Maoist student movement in the rural highland region of Ayacucho. It first became prominent in 1980 with attacks on civilians and government targets designed to disrupt national elections. Over the next two years, SL increased its range of violent activity in Ayacucho and in the neighbouring regions of Huancavelica and Apurímac, taking control of isolated villages and killing local officials and other ‘collaborators’.

Initially, government leaders appear not to have regarded SL as a serious threat. However, there was a gradual increase in the level of SL activity during 1981–82, and at the end of December 1982 emergency laws were introduced in regions of SL activity. Government military forces were granted extensive powers and were soon reported to be participating in the torture, rape and murder of villagers who were difficult to distinguish from the rebels who lived among them. At the end of 1982, SL formally engaged on Stage II of its revolutionary plan, the ‘protracted people’s war’, and both sides began to kill large numbers of non-combatant civilians.

The guerrilla war continued over the next decade, fought mainly in rural highland areas, but also occasionally in large cities. At its peak in the late 1980s, there were several hundred civilian conflict deaths per month. The main participants in the war were regular government police and army units, the Ejército Guerrillero Popular and other pro-government paramilitary groups, and SL. Some attacks were also carried out by the MRTA and by village self-defence groups (rondas campesinas), but these last two participants together accounted for only 3–4% of total civilian fatalities.

Throughout most of this period, Peru was a democracy, but many parts of the state forces operated independently of the elected government. In April 1992, President Alberto Fujimori instigated a coup d’état against the legislature. The Peruvian congress was dissolved, the constitution was suspended and many senior judges were removed from office. One of the stated aims of the coup was to give government forces a freer hand in suppressing insurgency. Then in September 1992, police captured SL’s leader, Abimael Guzmán, who had been hiding in a house in Lima. After Guzmán’s capture, the leadership of SL became fragmented. Early in 1993, Fujimori introduced a ‘repentance law’, offering an amnesty to SL fighters who surrendered and cooperated with the government; over 5,000 rebels made use of the amnesty over the next two years. Individual SL cells continued fighting, but by the late 1990s monthly civilian conflict fatalities had fallen to single figures, and the war was effectively over.

sec.title: Violence against civilians as a rational strategy
sec.p: In this section, we discuss the ways in which the level of terror chosen by one side in a conflict might depend on the level chosen by the other. If feedback effects between these quantities are positive, a shock that initially raises one side’s terror will have a multiplier effect over subsequent months, causing a sustained intensification of terror on both sides. We then discuss how a change in the level of different types of foreign aid might affect each side’s strategy. Finally, we draw together these ideas in the form of a statistical model of violence against civilians that can be applied to the Peruvian data.

sec.title: Interaction between insurgent and government violence
sec.p: The TRC reports the murder, rape, disappearance and torture of tens of thousands of civilians. It is far from clear that such violence is an effective military strategy, and indiscriminate violence often reduces the level of civilian compliance with the perpetrator (Kocher, Pepinsky & Kalyvas, 2011). Violence against civilians could arise from a culture of disregard for civilian welfare among military leaders, or a high cost of enforcing troop discipline (Hicks et al., 2011). However, the TRC reports many deliberate attacks on the poorest of villages where there was very little to loot, so it seems likely that much of the violence in Peru had an instrumental motive: leaders on each side believed that violence could be used to increase civilian compliance.

Therefore, our statistical model of violence against civilians is informed by a theory in which outcomes are a consequence of rational behaviour by the insurgent organization, the incumbent government forces and the civilian population. A distinction is to be made between the ‘core’ of the insurgency within the rebel organization, whose support for the cause is unconditional, and the ‘Umfeld’, the local civilian population who support the insurgency only if such support is likely to improve their welfare (Faria & Arce, 2005). Civilians can provide resources for the combatants on either side, including food, hiding places and recruits. One strategy to extract these resources is to encourage civilian support by offering rewards (Tosini, 2007), or by providing personal and economic security. 1 Another is to compel support through the use of intimidation and violence, or to use such violence to undermine support for the enemy by creating the impression that they are unable or unwilling to protect civilians. 2 In some circumstances, violence might be the most cost-effective tool to acquire material resources from civilians, or to mobilize troops. Changes in the level of violence reflect changes in the resource extraction strategy used by one or other of the combatants.

The strategies employed by each side are likely to be interdependent. Formal game-theoretic models of violence against civilians (for example, Bueno de Mesquita & Dickson, 2007) suggest that different types of strategy will be optimal in different conditions, and the optimal strategy will depend on the strategy of the enemy. Before modelling violence against civilians in the Peruvian civil war, we need to understand how the conditions there are likely to have affected the interaction between government and insurgent strategies. A useful starting point is the work of Wood (2010).

Wood’s research focuses on the incentives of insurgents, highlighting the two alternative strategies in extracting civilian support: the carrot and the stick. The carrot is the high-cost option: providing ongoing security or public services, which requires a substantial investment in infrastructure, whereas the intimidation of civilians requires just a few hours of foot-soldiers’ time. A weak insurgent group is unlikely to have the military or economic capacity to compete with the incumbent government in the provision of security and services. Using the Uppsala Conflict Data Program One-sided Violence Dataset, Wood shows that on average, insurgent violence against civilians is higher when there is low insurgent military capacity, where capacity is measured by relative troop numbers. However, this relationship is conditioned by the strategy of the government. If the insurgents possess adequate military capacity, then a higher level of government violence against civilians is associated with less insurgent violence (a negative feedback effect). In this case, the government’s abandonment of its role as security provider creates an incentive for the insurgents to try to fill this role. If, on the other hand, the insurgents lack such capacity, then a higher level of government violence against civilians is associated with more insurgent violence (a positive feedback effect). In this case, the insurgents’ limited resources mean that their only strategy is to compete with the government in the delivery of terror. 3

As Wood notes, another factor which might affect the intensity of insurgent violence against civilians is geography. In a sparsely populated area with high transport and communication costs, the insurgent leaders’ principal–agent problem will be more severe (Gates, 2002). Information about foot-soldiers’ incentives (Weinstein, 2005) and civilian loyalties (Kalyvas, 2006) will be more costly to acquire. Uncertainty about insurgent leaders’ degree of control over a remote area raises the incentive to use violence against civilians in order to ensure compliance. But further, the geography of the conflict conditions the insurgents’ response to an increase in government terror. High transport and communication costs raise the threshold level of insurgent capacity required for a reduction in insurgent terror to be a rational response to an increase in government terror. If costs are very high, it will be impossible for the insurgents ever to reach this threshold, so the provision of security and services for civilians is never a viable strategy. The same logic applies to government strategy, so if transport and communication costs are high enough then each side will respond in kind to an increase in terror perpetrated by the other.

It is also important to remember that violence against civilians occurs against a background of military engagements between the two sides and of changes in their resource capacity. This resource capacity can itself be influenced by the international community through changes in the level of foreign aid. Strategies relating to the treatment of civilians will not be independent of combat strategies, and both will depend on resource capacities. Some insight into these interconnections is provided by Azam & Hoeffler (2002), who develop a theoretical model to analyze the optimal strategy of a government when it can use terror to weaken support for the insurgents and therefore their combat strength. (By assumption in this model, the carrot is not a feasible strategy.) With a positive opportunity cost to the resources devoted to the conflict, the government will not spend all of its resources on combat strength and terror: in equilibrium, the marginal benefit of an extra dollar spent on military activity in terms of increasing the probability of victory will be equal to the marginal cost of the consumption foregone by the governing elite. However, an increase in the amount of available resources (for example, an increase in fungible foreign aid to the government) or an increase in the combat strength of the insurgents will raise the marginal value of both government combat strength and terror relative to their marginal cost, so government combat strength and terror will increase. Azam & Hoeffler do not explicitly consider the case in which insurgents also have an incentive to terrorize civilians, but their model could be extended in this way. In this case, any shock that increased the combat strength on one side would lead to a higher level of combat strength and terror on the other. A shock that raised the level of terror on one side would have the same effect. All feedback effects are positive.

Hultman (2007) suggests a further reason for a correlation between combat activity and terror. Insurgent leaders might interpret a failure on the battlefield as an indication that the return to further offensives against the government is low, and therefore increase the level of terror. Here, as in Wood (2010), terror is chosen as a low-cost option when engaging in battle is seen to be prohibitively expensive. In this case, a shock that increased the combat strength of one side would raise the other side’s terror but reduce its chosen combat strength, so there is a mixture of positive and negative feedback effects. Whether Hultman’s effects dominate those of Azam and Hoeffler will depend on the extent to which the outcome of one battle affects the expectation of future outcomes. In Peru, we have no a priori information on how sensitive expectations were to recent combat outcomes, so we remain agnostic about which effects dominate.

sec.title: Foreign aid fungibility, combatant resource capacity and violence against civilians
sec.p: The previous section suggests a mechanism through which foreign aid could increase both sides’ violence against civilians by raising the resource capacity of one side. Such a mechanism assumes that aid is fungible, that is, it represents an income stream which is not tied to specific expenditures. It assumes, for example, that the government can respond to an increase in aid for education by diverting some of its own resources away from education to fund terror. There is some evidence that aid is partly fungible, and that increases in development aid do lead to higher military expenditure (Collier & Hoeffler, 2007). However, there is no direct evidence on aid and terror. Moreover, if some aid is not fungible and if aid expenditure increases civilian incomes, then this will raise soldiers’ reservation wages and reduce combatants’ resource capacity (Collier & Hoeffler, 2002). The effect of development aid therefore depends crucially on its fungibility.

The importance of fungibility applies not only to development aid but also to military aid to the government. To the extent that such aid raises the government’s overall resource capacity, it should lead to more government violence against civilians and, with a positive feedback effect, to more insurgent violence. However, military aid might be tied to combat-specific investment in human and physical capital, which will raise combat productivity and induce a substitution of government resources out of terror and into combat activity. (Even so, the increase in government combat strength could then provoke more insurgent terror.) The effects on terror of military and development aid can differ because they work through different channels – the substitution effect versus higher soldiers’ wages – or because they exhibit different degrees of fungibility.

In addition to development aid and military aid, the United States has given aid to the Peruvian government specifically to eradicate coca production. The coca crop represented a lootable resource providing a rent-seeking incentive for the insurgency (Collier & Hoeffler, 2004). Revenues were not available to the government, which would risk losing international legitimacy if it traded in narcotics. The role of coca in funding the activity of SL is documented by Kay (1999) and Palmer (1992). In areas such as the Upper Huallaga Valley, SL operated as a middleman, running airstrips in remote locations and charging landing fees for planes transporting the coca crop to Colombia for processing. Estimates of coca production during the Peruvian war are rather imprecise, but it is estimated that the area under coca cultivation in Peru fell from around 100,000 hectares in 1992–95 to around 40,000 hectares by the end of the decade. To the extent that counter-narcotics aid was effective, 5 it would have diminished the resource capacity of the insurgents, reducing insurgent violence against civilians and insurgent combat strength, and therefore also government violence against civilians. However, this effect would be reversed if the reduction in total coca production induced SL to raise the implicit coca tax rate it imposed on peasants, and if ensuring compliance with the new rate required more terror.

sec.title: A formal model of violence against civilians
sec.p: In this section, we draw together the ideas discussed above to construct a statistical model of violence against civilians. This model will then be applied to the Peruvian time-series data. In moving from theory to data, we must bear in mind that we have no direct measure of combat activity. The TRC report focused on the civilian experience of the civil war, so we only have records of violent events in which there were civilian casualties; this must condition our interpretation of correlations between insurgent and government violence. Links between violence against civilians and combat activity are implicit in our empirical investigation, and our regression equations must be estimated in reduced form, with the (unobserved) level of combat activity solved out of the model.

We begin with a set of equations embodying the following properties.
More violence against civilians by one side, or a rise in that side’s combat strength, will lead to more violence against civilians by the other. This follows from the assumption that both sides find the carrot to be prohibitively expensive, and is consistent with Azam & Hoeffler (2002) and Hultman (2007), if their respective theories can be applied to both sides in the conflict.
More violence against civilians by one side will increase the other side’s incentive to raise its combat strength. Increased combat strength on one side might increase (Azam & Hoeffler) or reduce (Hultman) this incentive.
Aid of different kinds can affect the level of violence and combat activity on each side. However, the direction of the effect depends on aid fungibility.

sec.title: Data on civilian abuse and conflict intensity
sec.p:
Our main data source is the TRC. Over 2001–03, the TRC interviewed just under 17,000 witnesses to violence during 1980–2000 (Corazao et al., 2003). TRC transcripts provide information about individual violent events – the vast majority involving civilian victims – detailing the time and location of the event and which government or insurgent group initiated it. 6 These data have been collated by the Conflict Analysis Resource Table II.

Ball et al. conclude that the TRC documented the broadest range of perpetrators of violence and that it is the most comprehensive and consistent source of information about the conflict. Other organizations, which collected data contemporaneously, could not conduct surveys when the conflict was most intense, so we cannot pool data from different sources to produce a more accurate time series. (Also, other organizations were concerned mainly with government human rights violations, and appear to have substantially under-reported violence by insurgent groups.) Some conflict events are under-reported by the TRC; for example, rural events are less likely to be reported than urban events. However, there is no reason to suppose that there is any systematic variation over time in this type of bias, so time-series analysis of the TRC data can be expected to produce statistically consistent results.

Some of the cross-sectional variation in the data has already been analyzed (Castillo & Petrie, 2007; León, 2009). However, we are interested in the time-series variation. By aggregating individual observations in the database, we can construct monthly observations for the following quantities: the number of attacks initiated by regular government forces or paramilitaries, 7 the number initiated by insurgent forces, 8 the number of civilians killed or injured in government/paramilitary attacks, and the number killed or injured in insurgent attacks. Our time-series data are similar to those constructed for the civil war in Colombia (Restrepo, Spagat & Vargas, 2004, 2006).

The most direct measure of the level of violence against civilians is the number killed or injured by each side. However, there is likely to be some noise in the monthly civilian casualty series, because the precise number of casualties in any one attack will be partly a matter of chance. An alternative measure of violence is the total number of attacks. However, this measure will also be noisy if there is some random variation in the average size of attacks in a given month. 9 We will therefore fit two models of violence, one using the attack data and one using the casualty data. If the two models produce similar results, this increases confidence in the robustness of our results.

Totals for each of the four series are listed in Table IIa. One complication is that some of the attacks are not dated precisely enough to allocate them to a particular month, and we know only the year in which they happened; these account for about 25% of the total. In the results reported below, the imprecisely dated attacks are included in the following way. Let xt be the total number of observations of a particular dimension of the conflict (for example, insurgent attacks) in month t. Let xy be the total number of annual observations for that year (t ∊ y), and let xs = Σ t ∊ y
xt . In other words, xs is the sum of all monthly observations over the year. Our preferred measure for month t is xt' = [1 + xy / xs ] · xt ; that is, we scale our original monthly observations by the ratio of total observations for the year to total monthly observations. In other words, we allocate the observations that cannot be dated precisely in proportion to the relative level of conflict intensity apparent in the monthly data. (However, using xt instead of xt' to model the conflict makes very little difference to our results.) The four xt' time series are depicted in Figure 1 for the period January 1980–December 2000; more detail about the distribution of imprecisely dated attacks is provided in the online appendix.

Our model is not applied to all 20 years of data. Despite a number of casualties in isolated conflict events in 1980 and 1981, the ‘protracted people’s war’ began only in late 1982 (Tapia, 1997). Similarly, up until the end of 1982, the Peruvian government appears to have genuinely thought of the organization as a group of ‘cattle rustlers’ and ‘bandits’ (Fumerton, 2000). Recognition by both sides that they had engaged in a war apparently dates from the end of 1982. We will therefore model the conflict with data starting in January 1983. Dating the end of the conflict is less straightforward. Guzmán’s capture in 1992 caused serious disruption to the operations of a very hierarchical rebel organization, but the fighting continued. The introduction of the repentance law in early 1993 caused further disruption: over 5,000 rebels made use of this law up until its revocation at the end of 1994 (Palmer, 2007). This appears to have had a more substantial direct impact on rebel activity than Guzmán’s capture, and Figure 1 shows a sharp drop in rebel attacks at the end of 1993. If we extend the sample period beyond the end of 1993, the parameters in some equations become unstable. The results reported below are therefore based on fitting our model to data for January 1983–December 1993.

All four series in Figure 1 have distributions that are highly skewed, with a few very large observations in the right-hand tail of the distribution. When we try to fit a linear model to these series, we produce regression residual distributions that are highly skewed and fat-tailed. Small changes in sample size lead to large changes in estimated parameter values, suggesting that a linear model is not robust. These data are reported only annually, so in our monthly dataset the observation for month t is the logarithm of aid in the whole year including month t, measured in millions of US Dollars at 2000 prices. In the online appendix, we show that these variables are also stationary, except for narcotics aid. Nevertheless, the growth rate of narcotics aid is stationary. The variables used in our model are denoted military_aidt (US military aid), dev_aidt (total OECD development aid) and ▵12 cn_aidt (the annual growth rate of US counter-narcotics aid); we will allow for the possibility that the current and lagged values of these series affect the current level of violence.

In the previous section, we discussed how general development aid might affect violence through its effect on wages in the economy. A consistent estimate of this effect requires that we control for variations in economic conditions in Peru over the 13 years of the conflict. Alternative macroeconomic time-series indicators include real GDP, employment and inflation. The results reported below are based on models that include inflationt , the annual rate of consumer price inflation (measured monthly), as reported in the IMF International Financial Statistics; we did not find any other macroeconomic indicator to have a significant effect on our violence series. 10

We find that although there may be some bias of the aid parameters towards zero (so that our results should be seen as a lower-bound estimates of the aid effects), this bias is unlikely to be very large. We also find that the critical values appropriate for t-tests on individual parameters may be slightly larger than those in the Student’s t distribution. For example, the standard asymptotic 5% critical value of 1.96 may need to be replaced with a critical value as large as 2.3, depending on the seasonal pattern in aid flows. In the absence of any information about this seasonal pattern, we will take a conservative approach and use a critical value of 2.3.

Table III reports the parameters of the restricted model, along with corresponding heteroskedasticity-corrected t-ratios and diagnostic test statistics. There is some heteroskedasticity in one of the regression equations, but the regression residuals are approximately normally distributed and serially uncorrelated; there is no evidence of parameter instability. Table IV reports the residual correlation coefficients. All of these coefficients are positive, and some are significantly greater than zero.

sec.title: The dynamics of violence
sec.p:
Table II shows that in the attacks version of the model (
a t G
,
a t R
), the parameters on lagged insurgent and government violence are significantly greater than zero in both the insurgent violence equation and the government violence equation. In other words, the θ 1, θ 2, φ 1 and φ 2 parameters are all positive. In terms of Equations 1–4, this suggests that α 1 · β 1 < 1, and that α 1 and β 1 are either positive or not very large in absolute value. In other words, the direct positive feedback effects between insurgent and government violence against civilians dominate any indirect negative feedback effects via combat strategy. A shock that raises violence by one side in the current month can therefore be expected to lead to higher levels of violence by both sides in subsequent months.

One possible explanation for this difference between the two models is that the random variation in the number of casualties for an attack of a given intensity is greater than the random variation in the intensity of attacks, and that the extra noise in the killing model makes estimates of the autocorrelation coefficients more imprecise. This explanation is also consistent with the fact that the R2 statistics in the attacks model are greater than those in the killing model. Nevertheless, the positive values of θ 2 and φ 2 imply that there will be some persistence in the killing model as well as in the attacks model. How large are these persistence effects?

Using the aid coefficients in Table II, we can calculate the effects of an increase in a certain type of aid on violence over subsequent years. These effects are reported in Table V, which shows the change in each of the violence measures over the first two years following a sustained increase in counter-narcotics aid growth, military aid or development aid. For example, the top row of the table shows that a sustained 1% increase in military aid (around $53,000, on average) can be expected to raise government attacks by 0.06% after six months, a figure that rises to 0.08% after two years. With one exception (the impact of counter-narcotics aid growth on government violence), the magnitude of the effects does not vary substantially across the two versions of the model.

How are the aid effects to be interpreted? The negative coefficient on counter-narcotics aid growth appears in the government violence equations. A higher level of counter-narcotics aid can be expected to reduce insurgent income from coca, and therefore reduce insurgent combat capacity. The negative coefficient in the government violence equations suggests that government forces respond to the expected reduction in enemy combat capacity by reducing violence against civilians, which is consistent with Azam & Hoeffler’s theoretical model. There is no direct effect of counter-narcotics aid on insurgent violence: although such aid reduces insurgent combat capability, it does not immediately alter their preferred level of terror. (Why? Perhaps the negative effect of reduced resource capacity on insurgent terror is offset by the need to extract a higher rate of tax from coca when production falls.) However, there is a subsequent reduction in insurgent terror in response to the reduction in government terror, and these reductions are quantified in Table V.

The significance of military aid in the insurgent violence equations can be explained in a similar way. More military aid increases government combat capacity. The positive coefficient in the insurgent violence equations suggests that insurgent forces respond to this increase in enemy capacity by increasing violence against civilians, which is again consistent with Azam & Hoeffler’s theoretical model. There is no direct effect of military aid on government violence – the government neither increases nor decreases its level of terror (suggesting a moderate level of military aid fungibility) – and the long-run effect of a change in military aid on government violence in Table V is through the government’s response to increased insurgent violence.

The negative coefficient on development aid in the insurgent violence equations suggests that such aid does increase the opportunity cost of insurgent recruitment and that this limits the capacity of the insurgents to terrorize civilians. This interpretation is consistent with the final significant effect in Table II: worsening economic conditions, as captured by a higher inflation rate, are associated with more insurgent violence. There is no significant coefficient on development aid in the government violence equations; while the opportunity cost of government recruitment may also rise, the government may be able to divert some of the aid to cover its costs; in this case, there is a moderate degree of fungibility in development aid. Nevertheless, the reduction in insurgent violence following an increase in OECD development aid leads to a subsequent reduction in government violence, and these effects are shown in Table V.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Ball et al. (2003) estimate that Peruvian government and rebel forces killed 69,280 people during the war. Previous studies of wars in Peru and elsewhere have used cross-sectional data to analyze those characteristics of civilians and soldiers (and of the areas where they live) that are associated with a high risk of civilian abuse. In this article we have analyzed a different dimension of the data, looking at the factors that led to changes in the level of abuse during the war.

Our first main finding is that when one side in the war increased its level of civilian abuse, the other side responded in kind. There was a cycle of violence in which each side responded in the same way to activity by the other side. For this reason, some of the violence was predictable ex ante. This makes the war in Peru different from some other conflicts in which there are marked asymmetries in strategy – for example, the Israeli–Palestinian conflict. This lack of asymmetry could be explained by Peru’s geography: although the Peruvian government had far more resources at its disposal than the insurgents, the low population density and mountainous jungle terrain meant that neither side could realistically expect to provide military or economic security for the rural civilian population. For neither side was the carrot a realistic alternative to the stick. In such a conflict, encouraging or facilitating an increase in the government forces’ level of military capacity will only exacerbate the level of conflict and entail higher civilian casualties. The war in Peru was brought to an end not by the defeat of rebel forces in the field, but by the arrest of the rebel leader outside the theatre of battle and the subsequent amnesty offered to his lieutenants.

This leads to our second main finding: military aid to the Peruvian government led directly to an increase in the level of conflict intensity and the amount of civilian suffering. Such aid raised the fighting capacity of one side in the cycle of violence, but this was not sufficient to persuade the Peruvian government to abandon the patterns of behaviour of a weak belligerent. Instead, the increase in government military capacity led to an increase in insurgent terror, and subsequently to an increase in government terror. By contrast, both OCED development aid and specific counter-narcotics aid led directly to a decrease in the amount of civilian suffering. Development aid increased the opportunity cost of fighting, at least on the insurgent side, and counter-narcotics aid helped to weaken the insurgents by reducing their income. (Also, the aid was not so fungible as to offset these effects through an increase in the amount of government resources available for terror.) Through economic interventions, the international community has the capacity both to mitigate civil conflict and to exacerbate it: in Peru it did both.

fn.p: For example, the different paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland acquired a reputation for punishing apolitical criminals (Morrissey & Pease, 1982; Silke & Taylor, 2000). Similarly, the FMLN forces in El Salvador and the TPLF forces in Ethiopia provided a variety of public services in regions firmly under their control (Hammond, 1999; Poole, 2001).
Eck & Hultman (2007) show that civilian abuse by insurgents is more likely with a democratic government which needs to demonstrate that it can protect its civilian population.

Weinstein (2007) applies an alternative theory of violence against civilians to the conflict in Peru. Weinstein suggests that it was resource-rich rebels (for example, SL in the Upper Huallaga Valley) who were more brutal and non-selective in their use of violence, while resource-poor rebels (for example, SL outside of the main coca-growing areas) did not have the capacity to instil widespread terror and had to appeal to a common heritage or ideology to win support. Weinstein interprets attacks on civilians outside of the main coca-growing areas as ‘selective’ violence not intended to terrorize the whole rural population, but focused on government representatives, traders, landowners and religious leaders. (Attacks on whole villages resisting SL control are described as ‘mass selective violence’.) While it is true that most attacks targeted certain individuals, we contend that they still fall under the category of instrumental violence described by Wood as the tool of insurgents lacking the capacity to use a more benign strategy.

The analysis of Haushofer, Biletzki & Kanwisher (2010) indicates less strategic asymmetry in the Israeli–Palestinian conflict than is suggested by the Jaeger & Paserman results; nevertheless, marked asymmetries remain.

Figures presented at www.nytimes.com/2010/06/14/world/americas/14peru.html suggest that counter-narcotics aid was effective in reducing coca production in Peru in the mid-1990s, despite worries that police trained for counter-narcotics operations were used for more general military purposes.

A small fraction of attacks appear to have involved combat between insurgent and government forces, and it is possible that the resulting civilian casualties were accidental. Excluding these cases from our analysis makes no substantial difference to our results.
